articles.headline: Thousands Fleeing Qaddafi Bask in Tunisia’s Hospitality
articles.snippet: Most of the refugees are now living with Tunisian families in an area that in normal times counts just 150,000 residents.
articles.abstract: Most of the refugees are now living with Tunisian families in an area that in normal times counts just 150,000 residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: TATAOUINE, Tunisia — A century ago, fleeing Italian colonizers, the inhabitants of Libya’s remote western mountains descended upon this wind-whipped Tunisian outpost, many to stay permanently.

articles.headline: U.S. Seeks New Limits on Food Ads for Children
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission’s plan seeks to restrict the marketing of products like sugary cereals and fast-food meals to help stem childhood obesity.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission’s plan seeks to restrict the marketing of products like sugary cereals and fast-food meals to help stem childhood obesity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Will Toucan Sam go the way of Joe Camel?

articles.headline: PC Sales Off, Games Buoy Microsoft
articles.snippet: A slowdown in personal computer sales at Microsoft was overshadowed by strong sales of its Kinect and Xbox video game products.
articles.abstract: A slowdown in personal computer sales at Microsoft was overshadowed by strong sales of its Kinect and Xbox video game products.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Microsoft, once the dominant technology company, saw revenue from its core operating system software slip in the first three months of the year as consumers begin to shift to buying tablet computers that do not run on Microsoft software.

articles.headline: For the Fed, a Narrowing of Options
articles.snippet: Hopefully, Ben Bernanke will be right that the first-quarter stumble is “transitory.” But the Fed and the government could be caught in a bind if he isn’t.
articles.abstract: Hopefully, Ben Bernanke will be right that the first-quarter stumble is “transitory.” But the Fed and the government could be caught in a bind if he isn’t.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economic revival stumbled in early 2011. Could that be more than the “transitory” phenomenon that Ben Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, called it at his news conference this week?

articles.headline: China’s Exports Perch on Uncertain Truck System
articles.snippet: A disorganized and inefficient trucking system is creating a bottleneck for China’s export economy, and the problem could get worse.
articles.abstract: A disorganized and inefficient trucking system is creating a bottleneck for China’s export economy, and the problem could get worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — For years, China’s export juggernaut has been fed by highly efficient factories, low-cost labor and a fleet of container ships capable of transporting huge volumes of toys, textiles, electronics and other goods to every corner of the world.

articles.headline: Japan’s Crises Cut the Bottom Lines at Some Concerns
articles.snippet: Quarterly earnings statements show that the earthquake and tsunami in Japan have hurt American companies, especially those that do business there.
articles.abstract: Quarterly earnings statements show that the earthquake and tsunami in Japan have hurt American companies, especially those that do business there.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the earthquake and tsunami struck Japan in March, economists and corporate leaders knew it was only a matter of time for the financial effects to reach American companies.

articles.headline: Predicting Tornadoes: It’s Still a Guessing Game
articles.snippet: Tornado records have been shattered but scientists can only guess when and where tornadoes will actually strike.
articles.abstract: Tornado records have been shattered but scientists can only guess when and where tornadoes will actually strike.
articles.lead_paragraph: The cruelty of this particular April, in the number of tornadoes recorded, is without equal in the United States. The record for the month has been shattered, and preliminary assessments say that of the four biggest clusters ever recorded, two have occurred in the last three weeks.

articles.headline: In Shift, Egypt Warms to Iran and Hamas, Israel’s Foes
articles.snippet: Egypt is planning to open the blockaded border with Gaza and normalizing relations with two of Israel and the West’s Islamist foes, Hamas and Iran.
articles.abstract: Egypt is planning to open the blockaded border with Gaza and normalizing relations with two of Israel and the West’s Islamist foes, Hamas and Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt is charting a new course in its foreign policy that has already begun shaking up the established order in the Middle East, planning to open the blockaded border with Gaza and normalizing relations with two of Israel and the West’s Islamist foes, Hamas and Iran.

articles.headline: A Traditional Royal Wedding, but for the 3 Billion Witnesses
articles.snippet: The wedding between Prince William and Kate Middleton was an impeccably choreographed occasion of ancient customs tweaked by modern developments.
articles.abstract: The wedding between Prince William and Kate Middleton was an impeccably choreographed occasion of ancient customs tweaked by modern developments.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the end, Friday’s wedding between Prince William and Kate Middleton may not have ushered in a new dawn for the frayed royal family or brought a renewed era of optimism to a country beset by financial woes, as some predicted in the overheated countdown to the big day. But it proved that the British still know how to combine pageantry, solemnity and romance (and wild hats) better than anyone else in the world.

articles.headline: European Regulators Investigate Banks for Credit Swaps
articles.snippet: The investigations by the European Commission focus on possible anticompetitive behavior by the world’s biggest banks.
articles.abstract: The investigations by the European Commission focus on possible anticompetitive behavior by the world’s biggest banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since the financial crisis, when derivatives were blamed for exacerbating the panic, regulators have been looking for ways to make these complex financial instruments less risky. Now, regulators are also considering whether a small network of big banks unfairly controls the derivatives market itself.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and James Kanter
